section.title: Calibration and Validation of Urban Models
section.para: refer to book 7 and what is different in the data for calibration. this is why urban models are hard to calibrated, more complex models, data is poorer, more parameter interaction
less data (very little flow data), some height data of different qualities, height data is very influences by local factors, for example: bins, drains blocked, cars parked
calibrating to height not flow introduces a further level of uncertainty, though you dont have a lot of choice.
make the most of what you have - resident anecdotal

urban models tend to be more complex with a large number of parameter sets which can produce the same estimate but extrapolate differently. this parameter interaction makes determining parameters difficult and often makes options perform in unexpected ways
calibration adjustment can be on any number of parameters
parameters are interrelated
more parameters (compared to rural) = more parameter uncertainty, more parameter interaction
